post.title: Namecoin is dead, long live addresses
post.body:
Namecoin itself is a good drop-in replacement of DNS for decentralized networks, so it was natural to use it on ZeroNet. But it's only today when we realize that we were solving the wrong problem all the time.

Unlike Clearnet where you have to type facebook.com every five minutes to open a social network, ZeroNet has a homepage which shows all the sites you have downloaded -- ZeroHello. Show me any person who types `http://127.0.0.1:43110/sitename.bit` in the address bar instead of typing `sitename` to the site name filter on ZeroHello. The only moment when people actually use Namecoin is when sharing site links with others: it's easier to say 'sitename dot bit` instead of 'one capital A small b small c...'. Naturally, once you download the site, you don't use the domain at all, until you want to share the site with others.

So, what is the difference from Clearnet? In Clearnet, domains are mandatory and there are search engines. In ZeroNet, addresses are almost always enough to work (inefficiently but still) and there are no search engines. On Clearnet, there is archive.org and such, on ZeroNet many sites are run by enthusiasts and are easily forgotten.

ZeroNet is in a unique position when there is a possibility not to use domains the wrong way, and everyone uses them so. The officially recommended 'best practices' are to add `domain` field to content.json, which redirects everyone to the wrong address, should the domain be squatted. Also, ZeroName has a 'feature': expired domains still work until they are redirected by another person. **ZeroNet makes it look like everything is okay until domains break, and recommends doing so.**

What can we do about it? First, remove `domain` field from your sites immediately, although you may add the domain name to your blog sidebar or something. Second, do not use domains in hyperlinks, use raw addresses instead. Third, if you still need a domain, give a chance to non-expiring domains such as the ones provided by [Name.YO](/1NAMEz7stUPZErkV1d3yLkVWQFa4PTqDNv/).

post.title: The Sad Story of Terminal Emulators
post.body:
< ISO 2022 locking escape sequences oh flying
< spaghetti monster please kill me now.
< _— Actual USENIX peer review from the Mosh paper_

Terminals were invented before many of us were born, in the ancient times where people cared about standards, and browser incompatibilities weren't a thing. And yet, overcoming terminal problems is what I have to spend half of the time when I write CLI tools.

Long story short, I need to invent ~~the wheel~~ yet another terminal emulator, and like every lazy being, the first action I performed was to find an existing library. There are quite a few OSS emulators: Linux Console, Xterm, Alacritty, VTE-based emulators, Mosh, screen, tmux, etc.

What does the terminal emulator do, in the first place? It gets a character stream from programs, such as bash, tmux, vim, cat, etc., parses it, handles the control sequences and draws the text on screen. These control sequences are known as [ANSI escape codes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ANSI_escape_code), although not all of them are actually standardized by the ANSI committee. These control sequences are mostly used to control text color, style and position. The nearest analogy many programmers have heard of is HTML tags: `<b>` matches `ESC [ 1 m`, `<font color="red">` is `ESC [ 3 1 m`, etc. (Notice how the short name `red` gets a short code of 31, it is one of 8 colors that have a short code and don't have to be specified by their RGB components; the half-bug-half-feature is that these colors don't have a specific color assigned, and so most terminals provide a way to configure the actual color.) Most styles are primitive: there is no dynamic content, there are usually no images involved, there are no tables or flexbox. That said, the implementations vary, and getting reproducible behavior is 'slightly' impossible.

* * *

Let me state what I deem a definition of de-facto-standard-compliant terminal emulator: it should render my PS1 prompt. That's it. Don't think it's an easy criteria to meet, though. Here's how my shell looks like:

![image.png (1056x605)](data/img/post_11_image.png)

It consists of:

1.  Machine name on the left in yellow (the default yellow color, like `yellow` code),

2.  Next to it, the current username in blue (`rgb(0, 127, 240)`),

3.  Current branch name in pink (`rgb(255, 100, 203)`) -- there's a branch sign here that is only available in a specific font,

4.  A list of build systems of the package in dark magenta (`purple`),

5.  Current path in white, possibly abbreviated as `~username/relative_path` with the username part being yellow (`yellow`), and the path relative to Git repository root highlighted in cyan (`cyan`),

6.  Current date and time in my native locale in gray (`rgb(128, 128, 128)`),

7.  Previous command exit status marked with a light green (`rgb(100, 255, 100)`) tick or a light red (`rgb(255, 80, 100)`) cross,

8.  A green (`green`) dollar or a red (`red`) hash sign as user permissions indicator.

Actually, the first line of the prompt is asynchronous, i.e. first the tick/cross and the dollar/hash are rendered, and then a separate thread updates the previous line when all data is ready. This entire machinery (with a few additions which are irrelevant to this discussion) is handled by a 200-line bash script I wrote before going to bed and that I'm now afraid to touch, but it works so I got used to seeing such a pile of information in front of my eyes.

Anyway, you can see that the features in use are few in number: named colors, RGB true-color, font weight, cursor movement and position saving/restoring, so I didn't expect any problems when switching a terminal emulator. And yet all of them provide different results.

Here we go.

## libvterm (vshell)

![](data:image/png;base64,)

libvterm is 'an abstract C99 library which implements a VT220 or xterm-like terminal emulator'. It doesn't have a X backend by default, but it has a 'vshell' C script as a demo. This script uses libvterm to parse ANSI codes and then prints the result via ncurses. Although most styles are rendered correctly, it lacks the most expected feature: Unicode support.

## Vim

![](data:image/png;base64,)

I am not sure what backend Vim uses, but it definitely can't get cursor positioning right: the cursor coordinates don't get restored after rendering the first line. Also, notice how the yellow color got darker: it's because Vim doesn't know that when text color is specified with a name and rendered in bold, the color should be switched to the lighter variant.

## urxvt

![](data:image/png;base64,)

> urxvt is a customizable terminal emulator forked from [rxvt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rxvt "wikipedia:Rxvt"). Features of rxvt-unicode include international language support through [Unicode](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unicode "wikipedia:Unicode"), transparency, the ability to display multiple font types and support for [Perl](https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Perl "Perl") extensions.

In 2020, not all terminal emulators support true-color. But they question is why does `[master]` have such a strange background, shouldn't it have the default style like `[ivanq]`?

This is how the style of `[ivanq]` looks like: `ESC [ 3 8 ; 2 ; 0 ; 1 2 7 ; 2 4 0 m`. And this is the style of `[master]`: `ESC [ 3 8 ; 2 ; 2 5 5 ; 1 0 0 ; 2 0 3 m`. Both sequences consist of a _Control Sequence Introducer_ common to all style controls (`ESC [`), 'set foreground' ID (`3 8`), '24-bit' ID (`2`), three RGB space coordinates and a 'styling mode' terminator (`m`). Let's check the tables from Wikipedia -- see, the '2' digit from '24-bit' color space is treated as a font weight control, and '100' is handled as a 'set bright black background' (i.e. dark gray). Insanity? Yes, but that is how many parsers work (mostly regex-based, but others too): they don't handle errors at all and just skip the unknown numbers.

## GNU screen

![](data:image/png;base64,)

Screen is a 'full-screen window manager that multiplexes a physical terminal between several processes (typically interactive shells).' I've traced screen's history back to 1990, so it's wonderful that now in 2020 it supports Unicode, but a proper true-color support is missing.

## Xterm

![](data:image/png;base64,)

Nothing strange here, as expected: Xterm is the de facto standard of a terminal emulator. Notice that the branch sign is missing, but that is okay because I didn't set up the correct font.

## tmux

![](data:image/png;base64,)

> tmux is a terminal multiplexer: it enables a number of terminals to be created, accessed, and controlled from a single screen.

The first version of tmux was released in 2007, making it _GNU screen done right_, so it's no wonder it works way better.

## Mosh

![](data:image/png;base64,)

Mosh is a 'remote terminal application that allows roaming, supports intermittent connectivity, and provides intelligent local echo and line editing of user keystrokes.' Unlike ssh which just pipes shell input and output over network, Mosh configures a full-featured virtual terminal on the server side and sends the updates to the client. The important difference is that if a program sends a lot of output, not all of it is transferred over network, but only a few 'screenshots' at frame rate. And when the app outputs rainbow-colored text, which requires emitting at least 6 bytes per each characeter, the style attributes can be transferred in a compressed format.

Quote from Mosh website:

> Why you should trust Mosh with your remote terminal needs: we worry about details so obscure, even USENIX reviewers don't want to hear about them.

While working hard on the obscure details, they've forgotten about basic ANSI controls. And I was wondering why my apps didn't work in Mosh three years ago...

## Emacs

![](data:image/png;base64,)

And now something horrible: Emacs! I have no idea how incorrect a parser has to be to render this _so_ wrong. Anyway, I've always known Vim is better than Emacs, so there's little disappointment.

## Linux Console

![test.png (1024x174)](data/img/post_11_test.png)Finally, Linux Console is the 'official' Linux terminal because it's a part of the kernel, so it's not surprising that everything is handled correctly. The colors are slightly wrong, but that happens at rendering time: real colors are rounded to the safe ones.

## VTE-based terminals

![image.png (946x508)](data/img/post_11_image.png)

> VTE is a LGPL 2+ licensed library provising (sic!) a virtual terminal emulator widget.

VTE is a GTK widget for rendering a console. It's used by many terminals, like Gnome Terminal, XFCE Terminal, Terminator, etc. I have little to say, everything is rendered correctly.

## TerminalView

![](data:image/png;base64,)

TerminalView is a Sublime plugin for running a shell inside the editor. Sadly, it barely works. Notice that I had to leave the `cd Documents/libvterm/` command in the screenshot: that's because this terminal hangs on `clear`. By the way, see the strange smileys? That's how two control sequences (`0x01` and `0x02`) used by bash internally are rendered.

## Terminus

![](data:image/png;base64,)

Yet another Sublime terminal. And, no, it doesn't work as well.

## Conclusion

| _Terminal_ | Text rendering | Unicode | Positioning | True-color | Font effects | Total |
| --- | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | --: |
| Linux Console | + | + | + | + | + | 5/5 |
| VTE | + | + | + | + | + | 5/5 |
| Xterm | + | + | + | + | + | 5/5 |
| tmux | + | + | + | + | + | 5/5 |
| libvterm | + | - | + | + | + | 4/5 |
| urxvt | + | + | + | - | + | 4/5 |
| GNU screen | + | + | + | - | + | 4/5 |
| Vim | + | + | - | + | - | 3/5 |
| Mosh | + | + | - | - | + | 3/5 |
| Emacs | - | + | - | - | + | 2/5 |
| TerminalView | - | + | + | - | - | 2/5 |
| Terminus | - | - | - | - | - | 0/5 |

It turns out there are few Xterm-compatible terminals that aren't the originals in the first place: only VTE and, arguably, tmux implement the commonly used standard subset correctly.

So, what emulator should one use as a reference implementation when making a new terminal? Linux Console was written before the rest of the kernel and, as the rest, is hardly comprehensible. Xterm dates back to _before_ X server. tmux is not only a terminal emulator, but also a multiplexer, and it doesn't handle many styling commands because they are handled by the actual terminal (Gnome Terminal in my screenshot). VTE is a widget, sand a big part of it is GTK-specific and can't be reused.

So, sadly, there is no simple way to implement a terminal emulator nowadays. There are a few frontend-agnostic emulators such as [Pyte](https://github.com/selectel/pyte), but they all lack many features.

Does anyone want to write their own library for the open-source community?

post.title: Linux audio. Part 2
post.body:
This is the second part of **Linux audio** series.

## Volume

Let's try playing some music now. Make sure to turn volume down beforehand though. Open your favorite music player, choose a song. Slowly increase volume via Ubuntu UI or volume keys till you hear anything.

If you've turned volume to maximum and you still only hear silence, perhaps something is muted. We know that JACK doesn't control volume at all. In fact, Ubuntu UI controls PulseAudio volume so it shouldn't matter too. The only thing we haven't checked yet is ALSA.

* * *

## alsamixer

alsamixer is a fancy terminal application that controls ALSA, uh, mixer. There are several things we should check:

1.  **Master** controls all output volume, ensure that it's not muted (if it is, it shows **MM**, like below **S/PDIF**, if it's not, it shows **OO**, like below **S/PDIF De**). Try increasing its volume too.

2.  **Headphone**/**Speaker** is the physical output device, check the same stuff.

3.  Finally, check **PCM.**

![](data:image/png;base64,)

The audio should work now. Now, let's try running zynaddsubfx. Notice that jackd doesn't automatically make connections, so you have to connect zynaddsubfx output to the system output yourself (via qjackctl). It should work too.

## Volume synchronization

You might have noticed that zynaddsubfx volume and music player volume (actually, PulseAudio volume) are different. The reason is that it's affected by different things:

*   zynaddsubfx volume is affected by its internal volume settings and ALSA volume;

*   Music player volume is affected by its internal volume settings, PulseAudio volume and ALSA volume.

But even if we set the internal volume to maximum (that's what you should probably do anyway), the volumes are still different because of PulseAudio volume! What's even worse is that Ubuntu UI and volume keys allow you to change PulseAudio volume, so there's no way to change zynaddsubfx volume except using a slider inside the application or opening a terminal and running alsamixer. That's too far from great UX!

Luckily, the two sets have intersection: ALSA volume. If we could make Ubuntu change ALSA volume instead of PulseAudio volume, we'd be able to affect both PulseAudio apps and JACK apps!

Unfortunately, there's no builtin support for this.

## Scripting

If something is not supported, we can always implement it ourselves. Create file /usr/bin/set_audio_volume with the following contents:

```python
#!/usr/bin/python3
# By: Garrett Holbrook (August 27th, 2015), Ivanq (2020)
#
# Usage: Changes the system volume through amixer and then
#        makes a dbus method call to the gnome shell to get the
#        gnome volume OSD (On Screen Display)
#
# Requires: python3 and python-dbus (on Arch) or python3-dbus
#           (on Debian) or equivalent
import socket
import json
import sys

if sys.argv[1] == "server":
    import subprocess
    import threading
    import dbus

    # Getting the dbus interface to communicate with gnome's OSD
    session_bus = dbus.SessionBus()
    proxy = session_bus.get_object("org.gnome.Shell", "/org/gnome/Shell")
    interface = dbus.Interface(proxy, "org.gnome.Shell")

    # Start server
    def thread(sock):
        for line in sock.makefile():
            argv = json.loads(line)
            # Interpreting how to affect the volume and by what percentage and
            # then creating a bash command that will reduce the stdout to the
            # new percentage volume. Vol = volume
            name = argv[0]
            vol_action = argv[1]

            vol_percentages = list(map(int, subprocess.getoutput("amixer get " + name + " | grep -oP \"\\[\\d*%\\]\" | sed s:[][%]::g").split()))

            # Average them into a single value (note the +0.5 for rounding errors)
            vol_percentage = int(sum(vol_percentages) / len(vol_percentages) + 0.5)

            if vol_action == "toggle":
                if "[on]" in subprocess.getoutput("amixer get " + name + " | grep -o \"\\[\\(on\\|off\\)\\]\"").split():
                    subprocess.call("amixer set " + name + " mute >/dev/null", shell=True)
                    vol_percentage = 0
                else:
                    subprocess.call("amixer set " + name + " unmute >/dev/null", shell=True)
            else:
                vol_percent_change = int(argv[2])

                # Add/subtract the value of volume (handle negative values)
                if vol_action == "increase":
                    vol_percentage = max(0, (vol_percentage + vol_percent_change))
                else:
                    vol_percentage = max(0, (vol_percentage - vol_percent_change))

                subprocess.call("amixer sset " + name + " " + str(vol_percentage) + "% > /dev/null", shell=True)                subprocess.call("amixer set " + name + " unmute >/dev/null", shell=True)

                if vol_percentage == 0:
                    subprocess.call("amixer set " + name + " mute >/dev/null", shell=True)

            # Determining which logo to use based off of the percentage
            logo = "audio-volume-"
            if vol_percentage == 0:
                logo += "muted"
            elif vol_percentage < 30:
                logo += "low"
            elif vol_percentage < 70:
                logo += "medium"
            else:
                logo += "high"
            logo += "-symbolic"

            # Make the dbus method call
            interface.ShowOSD({"icon": logo, "level": vol_percentage / 100, "label": name + " (ALSA)"})

    serv_sock = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM)
    serv_sock.bind(("127.0.0.1", 26394))
    serv_sock.listen(5)
    while True:
        (sock, address) = serv_sock.accept()
        t = threading.Thread(target=lambda: thread(sock))
        t.daemon = True
        t.start()

sock = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM)
try:
    sock.connect(("127.0.0.1", 26394))
except ConnectionRefusedError:
    import subprocess
    import time
    subprocess.Popen(["set_audio_volume", "server"])
    time.sleep(1)
    sock.connect(("127.0.0.1", 26394))

sock.send((json.dumps(sys.argv[1:]) + "\n").encode())
```

This script is just a thin wrapper for amixer with On-Screen Display support (that square window that fades in at the center of the screen when you change volume). I'm starting a TCP server because I only want to import dbus once, and importing libraries in Python is rather slow.

You can now test the script by running `set_audio_volume Master increase 5` in terminal. You can use any ALSA device name instead of **Master**, e.g. **PCM**, **Headphones** or **Speaker**. I would recommend you to set everything except **Master** to 100% (e.g. via alsamixer) and only change **Master** volume.

## Volume keys

Now we're ready to add volume keys support. Perhaps the first thing you'd think about is to open **Keyboard Shortcuts** and disable **Volume down**, **Volume mute/unmute** and **Volume up** shortcuts. Plot twist: the shortcuts are already disabled. And if you assign some other key (e.g. Ctrl+F6), _both_ the original shortruct and the new one will work!

Instead, we have to change dconf. Start **dconf Editor**, open **org/gnome/settings-daemon/plugins/media-keys** and set **volume-down-static**, **volume-mute-static** and **volume-up-static** to `['']`. Restart Ubuntu. The default hotkeys should now be disabled.

Now, open **Keyboard Shortcuts** and add three custom shortcuts:

1.  Name: **Volume Mute (ALSA)**, command: `set_audio_volume Master toggle`, shortcut: **Audio mute**;

2.  Name: **Volume Up (ALSA)**, command: `set_audio_volume Master increase 6`, shortcut: **Audio raise volume**;

3.  Name: **Volume Down (ALSA)**, command: `set_audio_volume Master decrease  6`, shortcut: **Audio lower volume**.

The volume keys should work now and show an OSD like this when pressed:

![image.png (1440x900)](data/img/post_10_image.png)

## Connecting several output devices

This works well when you only have a single output device, e.g. builtin speakers, but you might want to connect external headphones. That is usually maintained by both ALSA and PulseAudio. But now we use JACK instead of PulseAudio, and JACK has no idea what "multiple" means, so only ALSA handles device switch. Unfortunately, ALSA sometimes does this wrong. For example, when I connect headphones, the internal speakers get muted but the headphones don't start playing audio. The reason is that ALSA is trying to auto-mute the current device when a new one is connected, but for some reason it doesn't unmute headphones. Time to make another script!

Create file **/usr/bin/jack_after** with the following content:

```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash
amixer sset Headphone unmute
amixer sset Headphone 100%
amixer sset Speaker unmute
amixer sset Speaker 100%
```

And **/etc/systemd/user/jackd-started.service**:

```ini
[Unit]
Description=Configure jackd connections.
Requires=jackd.service
Requires=pulseaudio.service
After=jackd.service
After=pulseaudio.service

[Service]
Type=simple
ExecStart=/usr/bin/jack_after

[Install]
WantedBy=default.target
```

What's done here is automatic output device unmute at startup. Don't forget to enable the service: `systemctl --user enable jackd-started.service`. After restarting Ubuntu you should see that the output devices are changed automatically.

## Sound cards? What sound cards?

JACK doesn't know what "multiple" means. Seriously, there's no builtin support for multiple sound cards. The only reason why connecting headphones worked in the previous section for me is that headphones and builtin speakers are usually on the same sound card, but that might not be false for your PCs and most likely won't work with USB devices (e.g. microphone).

The solution is to use **alsa_in** and **alsa_out** which are small programs that allow ALSA sound cards  to appear as inputs and outputs for JACK. Here's how to use them:

```
alsa_in -j "USB Microphone" -d hw:2 -q 1
```

The part after **-j** is the name of JACK input. The number after **-q** is quality (from 0 to 4). The string after **-d** is sound card ID which can be found out by running `arecord -l` in console, finding your card ID and adding **hw:** before the number.

```shell
ivanq@Ivanqs-Macbook:/$ arecord -l
**** List of CAPTURE Hardware Devices ****
card 0: MID [HDA Intel MID], device 0: CS4206 Analog [CS4206 Analog]
  Subdevices: 0/1
  Subdevice #0: subdevice #0
card 0: MID [HDA Intel MID], device 1: CS4206 Digital [CS4206 Digital]
  Subdevices: 1/1
  Subdevice #0: subdevice #0
card 2: CODEC [USB audio CODEC], device 0: USB Audio [USB Audio]
  Subdevices: 0/1
  Subdevice #0: subdevice #0
```

For output devices, replace **arecord** with **aplay** and **alsa_in** with **alsa_out**.

If this doesn't work for you, it's most likely because PulseAudio has already acquired the device. You can cancel that by running `pacmd list-cards`, finding your card (the ID might be different from the one reported by arecord!) and issuing `pacmd set-card-profile SOME_ID off`.

The good news is that this works well as long as the device is connected. The bad news is that it starts outputting lots of errors and using lots of CPU when it's disconnected. That's why I made a small script to kill **alsa_in** and **alsa_out** when the device is disconnected.

Save the following to **/usr/bin/alsa_in_nohang**:

```python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
import subprocess
import atexit
import sys

proc = subprocess.Popen(["alsa_in"] + sys.argv[1:], stdout=subprocess.PIPE)
atexit.register(lambda: proc.kill())

while proc.poll() is None and b"err = -19" not in proc.stdout.read(4096):
    pass
```

...and the equivalent code for **alsa_out**.

We can now run `alsa_in_hang -j "USB Microphone" -d hw:2 -q 1` (or similar) when the device is connected and don't think about any problems. The interesting fact is that if we run it when the device is already connected or acquired, nothing will crash.

* * *

In next article we'll automate device management and write a few more scripts.

post.title: Linux audio. Part 1
post.body:
< Linux is user friendly
< _— An old joke_

I am using Ubuntu 19.04\. For whatever reason, I decided to start working with audio on this machine (actually, I was connecting my Rockband Guitar and Drum controllers to Ubuntu; this involved some reverse-engineering, I can make a post about that if anyone is interested).

Pretend you want to play on the piano on the PC. On Windows, you'd just Google for a synthesizer. On Mac, you wouldn't have to Google at all: there's Garageband. On Linux, one of the first (and the best!) programs Google gives you is [zynaddsubfx](https://zynaddsubfx.sourceforge.io/). You download the app, run it, choose an instrument, press the key... press the key again... no sound.

* * *

## ALSA

![Screenshot of Alsamixer 1.0.14](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Alsa_v1.0.14_ubuntu7.1_en.png/1024px-Alsa_v1.0.14_ubuntu7.1_en.png)

Let's get a bit off-topic. Advanced Linux Sound Architecture (aka ALSA) is a software framework and part of the Linux kernel that provides API for sound card device drivers. To put it simply, ALSA manages sound cards and allows userland apps to control them, e.g. play audio.

What ALSA doesn't do is handling several audio sources at once. This makes it literally useless for desktop: say, a messenger would have to automatically detect which output device to use (e.g. by accessing global configuration), ask ALSA to give it exclusive control, beep and return the control to ALSA. It might look like it somewhat works, but actually it doesn't: in case you're listening to music, either there'd be no beep or music would be muted.

So, ALSA is never used directly on desktop.

## PulseAudio

![](data:image/png;base64,)

Such ALSA "stupidity" actually makes sense: you don't want much code in kernel space. Usually there's a userland program which has exclusive access to ALSA, and other apps (e.g. your favorite audio player, messenger, synth and so on) access it. One of such programs is PulseAudio which is used by Ubuntu.

PulseAudio is great for home usage, but it's really bad for recording studios and other professional stuff. Have you ever heard those clicks in the middle of the audio or short few-milliseconds pauses? There's a big probability it's caused by PulseAudio.

PulseAudio is a big monster that was made to do all things an average user might want to. It's rather slow, eats up resources and is not realtime.

However, PulseAudio is not the only program that can act as an "audio server", there are others that work better.

## JACK

![](data:image/png;base64,)

JACK (aka JACK Audio Connection Kit) is similar to PulseAudio, i.e. it controls ALSA and allows multiple programs to use a single input or output device at the same time. Actually, that's literally everything it does: it just maintains connections. However, such simplicity allows JACK to be almost instant, that's why it's used by musicians.

## Synth

Enough talk, let's get back to the zynaddsubfx silence problem. The problem is that zynaddsubfx only works with JACK, not PulseAudio. I've mentioned that both JACK and PulseAudio require exclusive access to a sound card (or device <span class="st">– the smallest object ALSA can give access to). Unfortunately, my only sound card (it's a laptop after all) was already acquired by PulseAudio, so JACK couldn't even start up.</span>

## Connecting PulseAudio and JACK

Perhaps the most straightforward solution would be connecting PulseAudio and JACK together: say, one of them could send and receive audio to/from another one. Of course, you don't want to ruin JACK nearly-realtime performance so you connect JACK right to ALSA, and let PulseAudio open ports on JACK. Enough talk, let's get to work.

Run the following in console:

```shell
$ sudo apt-get install pulseaudio-module-jack
$ pactl load-module module-jack-sink
$ pactl load-module module-jack-source
```

This will allow PulseAudio to connect to JACK. You should now see something like this in **PulseAudio Volume Control** (and perhaps some other devices):

![image.png (540x339)](data:image/png;base64,)

However, this is useless if JACK can't play audio. The solution is to start jackd when PulseAudio is off.

The easiest way to do this is to run:

```shell
$ pulseaudio --kill
$ qjackctl &
$ pulseaudio
```

...quickly, because PulseAudio automatically restarts, and that might happen before JACK acquires the sound card. After that, you should start JACK via qjackctl, and then set the default input and output devices in **PulseAudio Volume Control** to **Jack source** and **Jack sink**, respectively.

In the short run, this is the _easiest_ solution (see epigraph). However, you probably don't want to run all of these commands every time, so we can automate that with a systemd service.

Create the following file at `/etc/systemd/user/jackd.service`:

```ini
[Unit]
Description=Start jackd.
Before=sound.target
Before=pulseaudio.service
Requires=dbus.socket
After=usb-reset.service

[Service]
Type=dbus
BusName=org.jackaudio
ExecStart=/usr/bin/jack_control start
ExecStop=/usr/bin/jack_control stop
ExecStopPost=/usr/bin/pkill -9 jackdbus
SuccessExitStatus=0
RemainAfterExit=true

[Install]
WantedBy=default.target
```

...then stop jackd via qjackctl interface. Then start the jackd service by running `systemctl --user start jackd.service`. Now try opening qjackctl, it should show that jackd is running. If it does, you can enable the service (i.e. always run it on startup) with `systemctl --user enable jackd.service`. Try restarting Ubuntu.

**PulseAudio Volume Control** should now show a single device, both in **Input devices** and **Output devices**. Click the green tick next to them, this will make sure PulseAudio always passes its output and input to/from JACK. qjackctl should show a few wires from **system:capture** to **PulseAudio JACK Source** and from **PulseAudio JACK Sink** to **system:playback**.

* * *

ZeroBlog doesn't work with big articles well so I'm stopping now. The next part is coming soon.

post.title: Roadmap
post.body: Let's try using ZeroBlog as a TODO manager. * * * ## ZeroNet 1. [done] Websockets, a few bugs are caused by the switch from **gevent-websocket** to **gevent-ws** 1. [](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/2480)[done] [#2480](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/2480), potentially fixed by [#2483](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/pull/2483) 2. Dot files don't work, causes problems with daniell's hub 1. Waiting for [#2484](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/2484) to be resolved by nofish 3. Licensing 1. [#2269](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/2269) can be closed 2. Check if anyone else replies to [#2273](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/2273) 3. Remove/replace the code contributions specified in [comment](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/2273#issuecomment-599250757) 4. Remove/replace non-code contributions (e.g. translations), perhaps a bit harded 5. Replace the license 4. Optional files 1. [#2407](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/2407), looks like an easy task no one wants to do 5. Anonymity/safety/auto-purging 1. [#2465](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/2465), not sure if anyone needs that though or if that contradicts ZeroNet's goal 2. [#2350](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/2350), allowing custom auth_address. Useful for temporary accounts, e.g. for 0chan 6. Trackers 1. [#2374](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/2374), NAT-PMP and μTP support 7. PyPy 1. [#351](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/351), main issue 2. [python-tblib#58](https://github.com/ionelmc/python-tblib/pull/58), fixes pytest compatbility 3. [gevent#1541](https://github.com/gevent/gevent/pull/1541), applies the change to the gevent fork of python-tblib. Perhaps not going to be merged anytime soon, forking gevent might be a solution 8. Domain names 1. [#2214](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/pull/2214), adds DNS support, waiting for approval/test (?) 2. [#2164](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/pull/2164), adds ENS support, tests are failing, might want to resolve the problems and get this merged 3. [#2087](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/2087), a great topic on possible domain name systems, might want to implement some. The **.zeronet** part is connected to the ZeroNet plugin for browsers (see next section) 9. Frontend 1. [#2169](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/2169), reverse iframe proposal, no work for a long while. Might want to pick this up, most code is ready, just need to ensure the plugins work in all modern browsers 10. Standards 1. [#2464](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/2464), more protocols for frontend. Perhaps Gopher plugin was a good way to check that it's possible. Research what protocols could/should be added 2. [#2425](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/2425), standardizing ZeroNet and publishing specs, perhaps the right time to introduce ZOSC 3. [#2100](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/2100), standardizing protocol ## win-sudo 1. [#36](https://github.com/imachug/win-sudo/issues/36)

post.title: Integrated Encryption Scheme and MAC
post.body:
Today, we'll talk about MAC, DLIES and ECIES.

## DLIES

The first topic is DLIES, or Discrete Logarithm Integrated Encryption Scheme.

Pretend Alice wants to send a message to Bob. Alice doesn't want others to read the message, so she's going to encrypt it. Let's help Alice!

* * *

Pretend we have the following:

```
$
m - \space \text{the message to encrypt} \newline
p \in \Z - \space \text{finite field modulo} \newline
G \in \mathbb{F}_p - \space \text{the generator} \newline
b \in \mathbb{F}_p - \space \text{Bob's private key} \newline
B \in \mathbb{F}_p - \space \text{Bob's public key}
$
```

(of course, Alice doesn't have Bob's private key)

Here's what we're going to do now:

1.  Bob creates and shares the public key as `$B = G^b$`.

2.  Alice generates a random private key `$a \in \mathbb{F}_p$` and derives public key as `$A = G^a$`.

3.  Alice derives a shared secret `$S = B^a$` (you can notice that `$S = G^ab$`).

4.  Alice uses a symmetric cipher (e.g. AES or 3DES) to make ciphertext `$c = E_S(m)$`, where `$E_k(m)$` means "encrypt message `$m$` with key `$k$`".

5.  Alice sends `$A \Vert c$` to Bob.

Then, when Bob wants to decrypt the message, that's what he does:

1.  Bob receives the ciphertext `$c$` and Alice's public key `$A$`.

2.  Bob derives a shared secret `$S = A^b$` (you can notice that `$S = G^ab$`).

3.  Bob decrypts the ciphertext: `$m = E^{-1}_S(c)$`.

### Increasing security

Notice something interesting:

Alice generates a random private key for every message. This means that the shared secret is always different, and there is no way to get several messages encrypted with one key which is safer.

This, however, only means that a message can't be decrypted — this does _not_ mean that it can't be changed.

There are many symmetric encryption algorithms which allow you to change the message even if you don't have the private key: for example, flipping a bit in the ciphertext will also flip the same bit it in the message.

Here's what you could do: if you know that the message looks the following way:

> Hello! You wanted to send me the payment for my work, do you remember this? Please send it to this bitcoin address: 1HeLLo4uzjaLetFx6NH3PMwFP3qbRbTf3D.

Here's what you could make it look like:

> Hello! You wanted to send me the payment for my work, do you remember this? Please send it to this bitcoin address: 1FwH89xyniDgy3t6fCWrggLs22MnGPZ5K5.

Oops.

There's also another similar problem: Bob has no idea who sent him the message. If someone knows Alice's public key, he can send garbage to Bob, which could, however, do something bad.

Oops.

## MAC

> Some people, when confronted with a problem, think, “I know, I’ll use regular expressions.” Now they have two problems.

On the other side, MAC solves two problems, and that's exactly what we're looking for.

First of all, what's MAC? MAC stands for "Message Authentication Code".

Pretend you have a magic function `$MAC_k(m)$` that somehow returns a proof that you have the private key `$k$` and the message `$m$` hasn't been changed. What would you do then?

We can update DLIES with the following step:

*   When Alice wants to send a message to Bob, she does the following:

    1.  Generate the encryption key and the MAC key via `$k_E \Vert k_{MAC} = B^a$`.

    2.  Get the ciphertext: `$c = E_{k_E}(m)$`.

    3.  Get the MAC: `$d = MAC_{k_{MAC}}(c)$`.

    4.  Send `$A \Vert d \Vert c$`.

*   When Bob wants to receive a message from Alice, he does the following:

    1.  Generate the encryption key and the MAC key via `$k_E \Vert k_{MAC} = A^b$`.

    2.  Verify MAC: if `$d \neq MAC_{k_{MAC}}(c)$`, stop.

    3.  Decrypt the message: `$m = E^{-1}_{k_E}(c)$`.

## ECIES

Elliptic curves are better than integers, right? Let's think how to use our knowledge to apply EC here!

First, we of course know how to generate the public key: `$A = aG$`. Second, we can use X coordinates everywhere where we need integers.

So, here's the algorithm for encryption:

1.  Generate random private key `$a \in \mathbb{F}_n$`.

2.  Generate public key `$A = aG$`.

3.  Derive encryption key and MAC key `$k_E \Vert k_{MAC} = x_{aB}$`.

4.  Generate ciphertext `$c = E_{k_E}(m)$`.

5.  Generate MAC `$d = MAC_{k_{MAC}}(c)$`.

6.  Send `$x_A \Vert y_A \Vert d \Vert c$`.

The decryption algorithm is the following:

1.  Derive encryption key and MAC key `$k_E \Vert k_{MAC} = x_{bA}$`.

2.  Check MAC: if `$d \neq MAC_{k_{MAC}}(c)$`, stop.

3.  Decrypt message `$m = E^{-1}_{k_E}(c)$`.

post.title: Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman
post.body:
Hello! Today I'm going to tell you about ECDH, or Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman protocol.

First of all, let's remember what EC means and what DH means.

1.  EC is an Elliptic Curve. You can read about [Elliptic Curve arithmetic](?Post:1:Introduction+into+Elliptic+Curve+arithmetic) on this blog. If you don't want to read it, here's an overview: We have some objects (points) which we can add. The usual rules apply, i.e. `$A + B = B + A, (A + B) + C = A + (B + C)$`.

2.  DH is Diffie-Hellman protocol, i.e. a key derivation protocol. You can read about it [on this blog](?Post:2:Diffie-Hellman+protocol) as well. An overview: If Alice and Bob have private keys `$a$` and `$b$` they don't share, they can make up some integers `$G$` and `$M$` (`$G$` is any integer, `$M$` is a big prime integer). Then, they generate public keys: `$A = G^a \mod M, B = G^b \mod M$` which they give to each other. Then, they generate shared key that they use for symmetric encryption: `$S = B^a \mod M = A^b \mod M$`.

Now, we're going to merge these two unmergable things. How? Read here.

* * *

Let's just repeat everything we did when we were making Diffie-Hellman protocol, step by step.

### Modulo arithmetic for the win

The security of Diffie-Hellman protocol mostly depends on the modulo operation. So, let's do the same with elliptic curves.

How we defined an elliptic curve is: `$y^2 = x^3 + ax + b; a, b \in \R$`. So, this is how we'll define it now: `$y^2 \equiv x^3 + ax + b; a, b \in \mathbb{F}_p$` (`$\mathbb{F}_p$` is also known as `$\Z/p$` — basically, the remainder of division by `$p$`).

Actually, we have some problems now.

Here's how the `$y^2 = x^3 + 7$` looks like over real numbers:

![](https://en.bitcoin.it/w/images/en/b/bf/Secp256k1.png)

And this is how it looks over `$\mathbb{F}_{59}$`:

![elliptic_curve_59](https://habrastorage.org/files/48a/74b/f17/48a74bf177fc4bb0bfa86678bccf6125.png)

It not only doesn't look like a curve anymore — we can't even define what's a line now!

* * *

However, this is actually not a problem. Remember how we defined addition:

```
$
s = \frac{y_P - y_Q}{x_P - x_Q} \newline
x_R = s^2 - x_P - x_Q \newline
y_R = -y_P + s(x_P - x_R) \newline
\text{Or, in case of tangent:} \newline
s = \frac{3 x_P^2 + a}{y_P + y_Q}
$
```

We use modulo arithmetic now, so we replace division with multiplication by the inverse:

```
$
s \equiv (y_P - y_Q)(x_P - x_Q)^{-1} \newline
x_R \equiv s^2 - x_P - x_Q \newline
y_R \equiv -y_P + s(x_P - x_R) \newline
\text{Or, in case of tangent:} \newline
s \equiv (3 x_P^2 + a)(y_P + y_Q)^{-1}
$
```

And we don't even need to check whether a point belongs to the curve, or whether three points are on the same line! We actually don't use geometrical interpretation anymore.

### Bringing a bit more to EC arithmetic

Addition is definitely not enough to do anything. Look, the classic Diffie-Hellman protocol uses _power_ — i.e., it's the "3rd order" operation: first addition, then multiplication, then power. Adding points to each other is definitely too boring and doesn't make any sense in cryptography, right?

No problem. We're adding multiplication!

`$nA = \underbrace{A + A + \dots + A}_{n \space \text{times}}$`

Notice that you don't multiply points here — you multiply an integer by a point.

However, if you try to use the formulas above, you'll notice that `$G, 2G, 4G$` and `$123G$` are very different, and there's practically no way to get `$G$` from `$123G$`.

That's exactly what we want!

We used power in classic Diffie-Hellman because that's the inverse (logarithm) operation can't be done fast. And we'll use multiplication in ECDH because the humanity doesn't know how to divide in EC.

### The generator power

There's one small point we have forgotten to talk about: what's exactly a private key?

We want it to be such a value that there's no way to get it from the public key. We also want to have at most one private key that gives a specific public key, i.e. `$\forall a, b; a \neq b: aG \neq aB$`. Basically, we want the multiplication be an ideal hash function.

Oops, we have a problem.

We thought that `$iG$` will never loop. But it does. You'll probably ask: when? The most dumb answer would be "at `$i = p$`". Think again...

The answer is: we have no idea. We can calculate this value, called "the power of a point", i.e. the minimum `$n \in \N$`, such that `$nG = O$` using special algorithms. And, the result might not be really good — you probably shouldn't use such a generator point that has a power of 17.

There's also a similar value, `$h$`, defined as `$h = \frac{|E(a, b)|}{n}$`. It can be proven that `$h \in \N$` (via Lagrange's theorem).

So, you should make sure that the power is big enough, i.e. there are many enough different public keys.

### Merging everything together

Pretend you have

```
$
p \in \N, p \space \text{is prime}; \newline
a, b \in \mathbb{F}_p; \newline
G(x_G, y_G): x_G, y_G \in \mathbb{F}_p, y_G^2 \equiv x_G^3 + a x_G + b
$
```

`$G$` is called "the generator".

A private key is still an integer, i.e. `$s_A, s_B \in \mathbb{F}_n$`. Then, we define `$hash(s_A) = s_A G$`, i.e. a public key is _a point_! We can now define `$derive(B, S_A) = S_A B$`. So: `$S = derive(B, S_A) = S_A B = S_A S_B G = S_B S_A G = derive(A, S_B)$`. We now have a _shared point_, which of course can't be used as a key — but we can use it's X coordinate.

_Notice that I used `$S_A$` and `$S_B$` for private keys here to avoid confusion with curve's `$a$` and `$b$` parameters._

post.title: Diffie-Hellman protocol
post.body:
Hello again!

Today, let's talk about key derivation.

### The problem

Pretend Alice and Bob are talking to each other, and they want to encrypt their messages. Of course, encryption requires a key, so they have to find a key somewhere. They could just meet in Alice's house, but... Alice and Bob are _a little bit_ far from each other, so they can't meet directly. They also can't use mail to send the key because it could be compromised, and so on.

Oopsie.

* * *

### Private-key cryptography

So, if you can't share the key, just make it for yourself, right? Pretend Alice generates a private key `$a$`, and Bob generates a private key `$b$`. Let's now transform the private keys into public keys. Say we have some hashing algorithm, then `$A = hash(a)$`, `$B = hash(b)$`. Of course, the hashing is performed by Alice and Bob, respectively. They can now give the public keys to each other using mail.

Now, the task is to make a key-derivation function, such that `$derive(B, a) = derive(A, b)$`. This result is called a shared key. If we find such function, Alice will calculate `$S = derive(B, a)$`, and Bob will calculate `$S = derive(A, b)$`. They now have a shared key and can use it for encryption.

So:

*   Alice: `$B, a \to S$`

*   Bob: `$A, b \to S$`

*   Charlie (i.e. anyone else): `$A, B \to \text{:(}$`

### Ah, "key derivation" you said...

Actually, there are two functions we have to implement: `$hash$` and `$derive$`. And, surprisingly, this is exactly what we need!

Let's say that `$a$` and `$b$` are some big natural numbers. Then let's define our functions the following way:

```
$
hash(a) = G^a \newline
derive(A, b) = A^b
$
```

First of all, it _does_ work correctly:

`$derive(hash(a), b) = (G^a)^b = G^ab = (G^b)^a = derive(hash(b), a)$`

We can now take `$G = 3$`, and Alice and Bob can generate the shared key.

But... is this safe?

### Discrete logarithm problem

Pretend you're an attacker. Of course, you want to get the shared key to decrypt the messages. What do you have? Only `$A$` and `$B$`.

The Diffie-Hellman problem looks somewhat like the discrete logarithm problem. Here it is:

> Given `$G$`, `$G^a$` and `$G^b$`, can you find `$G^ab$`?

Unfortunately, it's solvable in our case. Since `$A$` can't be really large (come on, a public key cannot weigh a megabyte), it obviously can't be more than `$3^{100000}$`. So, you can just try `$a = 1, a = 2, a = 3$` and so on. This will take at most 100000 steps — not that much!

Oops.

### Modulo

Modulo arithmetic is a silver bullet in cryptography.

If we don't want big numbers and you want to be safe, just use modulo. Let's say `$M = 2367495770217142995264827948666809233066409497699870112003149352380375124855230068487109373226251983$` (that's just a random big prime number). Now, define `$hash(a) = G^a \mod M$`. Now, you can calculate `$hash(a)$` in logarithmic time, so you can take as big `$a$` as you want. However, the humanity knows no way to restore `$a$` from `$G^a \mod M$` — and this is the main idea.

## Conclusion

If Alice and Bob have private keys `$a$` and `$b$`, they can generate public keys using `$A = G^a \mod M, B = G^b \mod M$` rule. Now, they can send the public keys to each other. They both can now calculate a shared secret `$S = A^b \mod M = B^a \mod M$` and use it for encryption. All of this can be done in logarithmic time.

post.title: Introduction into Elliptic Curve arithmetic
post.body:
Today, let's talk about Elliptic Curve arithmetic.

## Elliptic curves

First of all, what is an elliptic curve? If we're working in `$\R$` field, we can say that an elliptic curve is defined by two real numbers `$a$` and `$b$` that follows the equation:

```
$
x^2 = y^3 + ax + b
$
```

This form is called the [Weierstrass equation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weierstrass%27s_elliptic_functions).

* * *

We should also mention that this curve should be non-singular, for example:

![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/EllipticCurveCatalog.svg/392px-EllipticCurveCatalog.svg.png)

If `$a = b = 0$` the curve is non-singular, and thus it's not an elliptic curve.

## Interesting properties of elliptic curves

Pretend we have two different points `$P$` and `$Q$` both belonging to an elliptic curve. If we draw a line through them, we can see that, in some cases, it intersects the curve in 3 points (including `$P$` and `$Q$`), and sometimes in two points (`$P$` and `$Q$` themselves), but you'll never have 4 points (or more) on the same line.

_What does this mean?_

Let's say that, for any `$P$`, `$Q$` and `$R$` belonging to the same line, `$P + Q + R = O$`.

Notice that the `$O$` point is not really a point, but rather a special value.

We can now find some interesting properties, for example:

1.  The elliptic curve is symmetric. For example, if `$(x, y)$` belongs to the curve, `$(x, -y)$` will do as well. Let's define `$-P = (x, -y)$` if `$P = (x, y)$`.

2.  If you draw a line through `$P$` and `$-P$`, it won't have any other intersection points. In this case, let's say that `$P + (-P) + O = O$`.

3.  `$\forall P, Q, R: P + Q + R = Q + P + R$`

4.  `$\forall P, Q: (P + Q) + R = P + (Q + R)$`

5.  Since `$Q$` and `$R$` may be the same point, any other `$P$` would be okay. Instead, let's say that we want such `$P$` that it is the only other point of intersection. In fact, this means that the line is the tangent. Thus, `$\forall P, Q: P + Q + Q = O \iff PQ \space \text{is a tangent}$`.

6.  Since `$O$` may be an argument, let's say that it belongs to any line, i.e. it's a neutral element — thus, `$\forall P, Q: P + Q + O = O$`.

7.  If we combine 5\. and 6., we get that `$\forall P: P + P + O = O$`.

![ECClines.svg (680x206)](data/img/post_1_ECClines.svg)

So, now we understand that `$O$` should be a neutral element to make at least some sense.

### Addition

So, why did we need this?

`$P + Q + R = O \implies P + Q = -R$`

Woah!

If we say that `$O$` is the same as a zero in real numbers, we now get an algorithm to get the sum of two points.

1.  Draw a line through `$P$` and `$Q$`.

2.  Intersect it with the curve and get `$R$`.

3.  Invert `$R$`.

Moreover, we can notice that all the usual properties apply, i.e.: `$P + Q = Q + P$` and `$(P + Q) + R = P + (Q + R)$`.

### Algebraic implementation

Instead of using geometrical interpretation which would be difficult to transform into formulas, we'll use the following rule:

Given `$x_P, y_P, x_Q, y_Q$`, we get `$x_R$` and `$y_R$`, such that `$P + Q = R$`.

```
$
s = \frac{y_P - y_Q}{x_P - x_Q} \newline
x_R = s^2 - x_P - x_Q \newline
y_R = -y_P + s(x_P - x_R)
$
```

If `$x_P = x_Q$`, i.e. `$s$` is not defined, and `$y_P = -y_Q$`, it's easy to notice that `$P + Q = O$`, and, thus, `$R = O$` as well. Notice that the `$P = Q = O$` case is handled here as well.

If `$x_P = x_Q$`, and `$y_P = y_Q \neq 0$`, we want the tangent, thus:

```
$
s = \frac{3 x_P^2 + a}{y_P + y_Q}
$
```

I won't prove this fact here, but you can notice that it gives the same results as the geometrical way.

* * *

## Conclusion

An elliptic curve is defined the following way: `$y^2 = x^3 + ax + b$`. We can define addition, such that, given two points (or zeroes) `$P$` and `$Q$`, we can get `$R$`. This "addition" follows the `$P + Q = Q + P$` and `$(P + Q) + R = P + (Q + R)$` properties.

Why would you need this? I'll tell you the next time.
